title: RL30787
content: House procedures in the House of Representatives are not solely based on the Rules adopted at the beginning of each new Congress. They also include constitutional mandates, parliamentary principles in Jefferson's Manual, laws that act as rules, precedents, committee rules, and party caucus/conference rules. These parliamentary authorities are cited by members when raising points of order or defending against them. The House Manual contains the chief authorities governing parliamentary procedure, including the Constitution, Jefferson's Manual, House Rules, and relevant laws. The House Manual contains the chief authorities governing parliamentary procedure in the House of Representatives, including the Constitution, Jefferson's Manual, House Rules, and rule-making statutes. Official reference documents compile and digest the precedents of the House, such as House Practice, Deschler's Precedents, Hinds' and Cannon's Precedents, and parliamentary reference documents prepared by committees. The House Manual contains key authorities for parliamentary procedure in the House of Representatives, including the Constitution, Jefferson's Manual, House Rules, and rule-making statutes. Official reference documents compile precedents of the House, such as House Practice, Deschler's Precedents, Hinds' and Cannon's Precedents, and parliamentary reference documents prepared by committees. The House Committee on Rules compiles Committee rules, Floor Procedure, and other parliamentary reference sources for each Congress. The report reviews House procedure principles and describes the format and content of these reference documents. The curr_chunk provides detailed information on how to locate parliamentary reference documents in various sources, including printed materials and the internet. It also includes appendices summarizing the information contained in the access boxes. Additionally, it mentions that official guidance on House parliamentary procedure is available from the Office of the House Parliamentarian and CRS staff can assist in clarifying House rules and procedures. The House parliamentary procedure is governed by multiple authorities, not just chamber rules. House rules are not self-enforcing, and the House rarely disregards its precedents. The House adheres to many practices that have developed informally. The rules of the House are not the only authority governing parliamentary procedure. The interaction among various authorities affects procedural situations. The House's parliamentary procedure is influenced by various authorities, not just its own rules. The Constitution grants the House the power to establish its procedural rules, which are determined at the start of each Congress. Special rules and rule-making statutes also play a role in shaping House procedures. The House uses its rule-making power to establish procedural rules, including special rules and rule-making statutes. These rules have the same standing as the House's official rules and are created through the House's constitutional authority. The House's rule-making authority allows it to establish procedural rules, including special rules and rule-making statutes. These rules are enacted as an exercise of the rule-making authority of each house and can be suspended or waived by the House through various voting procedures. The House can adopt a special rule to waive points of order raised by Members regarding violations of House Rules or procedural authorities. The chair rules on the validity of points of order, and if sustained, the House cannot proceed with the action. The chair may also refuse to entertain proposed actions that violate House Rules or other procedural authorities. The chair enforces House Rules and procedural authorities by refusing actions that violate them. The chair may rule actions out of order or remind members of decorum. Without a point of order, the House can proceed contrary to procedural requirements. The chair only rules on procedural questions, not constitutional matters. Constitutional matters are settled by a vote of the body. The chair enforces House Rules and procedural authorities by refusing actions that violate them, but does not have authority over constitutional matters. Constitutional questions are settled by a vote of the body, while party caucus rules and informal practices do not have the same standing as House Rules. Committee procedures are generally not enforceable on the House floor. The House chair enforces rules and procedures, while constitutional matters are decided by a vote of the body. Party caucus rules and informal practices do not hold the same weight as House Rules. Committee procedures are typically not applicable on the House floor. Precedents are established through chair rulings, appeals to the House, and procedural decisions by majority vote. The House rarely entertains appeals of chair rulings and often confirms them by laying appeals on the table. Precedents in the House are established through chair rulings, appeals, and procedural decisions by majority vote. They influence the application of current House rules by relating past decisions to the specific case at hand. Members cite precedents to support their arguments, similar to how attorneys cite case law in court. The House rarely disregards its precedents, which carry varying weights based on the chair's disposition of points of order. Precedents in the House are established through chair rulings, appeals, and procedural decisions by majority vote. They influence the application of current House rules by relating past decisions to the specific case at hand. Precedents carry varying weights based on the chair's disposition of points of order and decisions by the House. Members may seek official advice from the Parliamentarian of the House to find precedents to support or rebut arguments. Some House procedural actions are based on informal practices that have evolved over the years. House procedural actions are often based on informal practices that have evolved over time. These practices, although not formally adopted, are rarely challenged on the House floor. Examples include the Speaker's recognition of Members for speeches and giving priority to committee members reporting a bill for offering floor amendments. The House Manual compiles authoritative parliamentary sources with annotations summarizing relevant precedents and practices. The House Manual compiles parliamentary sources with annotations summarizing precedents and practices relevant to House proceedings. It includes the Constitution, Jefferson's Manual, adopted House Rules, and rule-making statutes. Published by the Government Printing Office as an official House Document in each Congress, it is often referred to as "Jefferson's Manual." The House Manual, also known as Jefferson's Manual, is published by the Government Printing Office as an official House Document in each Congress. It includes parliamentary authorities with annotations summarizing precedents and practices relevant to House proceedings. The Manual is organized in numbered sections and features a comprehensive index, annotations by the Parliamentarian, and a preface summarizing changes to House Rules since the last Congress. The House Manual, also known as Jefferson's Manual, is published by the Government Printing Office as an official House Document in each Congress. It includes parliamentary authorities with annotations summarizing precedents and practices relevant to House proceedings. The Manual is organized in numbered sections with a comprehensive index, annotations by the Parliamentarian, and a preface summarizing changes to House Rules since the last Congress. The Manual's section numbers facilitate citation and reference across editions, with citations usually given by section number rather than page number. The House Rules were recodified in the 106th Congress, reducing their number from 52 to 28, which led to changes in section numbers in the Manual. The extensive index provides citations by section number, breaking major topics into subheadings with descriptive specifications for each provision cited. The House Manual, also known as Jefferson's Manual, includes parliamentary authorities with annotations summarizing precedents and practices relevant to House proceedings. The index breaks major topics into subheadings with descriptive specifications for each provision cited. Annotations by the Parliamentarian provide historical context and information on contemporary application, including important precedents. The curr_chunk provides information on citations to important precedents in various official publications, including formats like Congressional Record, Hinds' and Cannon's Precedents, Deschler's Precedents, and Procedure in the House. It explains how these citations are presented and refers the reader to specific volumes, chapters, and sections for further details. The curr_chunk discusses the practical value of precedents in the parliamentarian's annotations, showing the relationship between specific clauses and precedents. It also highlights the importance of updated discussions in the House Manual for referencing important precedents not included in earlier compilations. The citations provided serve as a time-saving research tool for readers seeking precedents related to specific clauses of House Rules or parliamentary procedures. The curr_chunk discusses the House Manual's inclusion of important precedents not found in earlier compilations, with citations provided as a research tool for specific clauses of House Rules. The Manual presents the Constitution with annotations by the parliamentarian, explaining interpretations and applications by the House and courts, particularly regarding procedural requirements in Article I, section 5. The curr_chunk discusses how the House interprets and applies constitutional provisions, including procedural requirements in Article I, section 5. It highlights the House's authority to adopt rules, keep an official journal, require a quorum, and conduct yea and nay votes. The parliamentarian's annotations provide practical applications of these provisions. Additionally, House Rule XXVIII incorporates Jefferson's Manual for parliamentary practice. Thomas Jefferson wrote the Manual of Parliamentary Practice for the Senate of the United States, based on British House of Commons practices. Despite being intended for the Senate, it is not considered an authority on Senate procedure today. Jefferson's Manual is distinct from the House Manual and the Rules of the House, with annotations explaining its relevance to current House procedures. The Manual of Parliamentary Practice by Thomas Jefferson, specifically relevant to House parliamentary procedure, includes annotations by the parliamentarian explaining how Jefferson's practices relate to current House procedures. The House adopts Rules at the start of each Congress, usually re-adopting previous Rules with amendments recommended by the majority party. The House Manual presents Rules clause by clause with annotations, allowing for changes to be made during a Congress. The House adopts Rules at the start of each Congress, usually re-adopting previous Rules with amendments recommended by the majority party. The House Manual presents Rules clause by clause with annotations, allowing for changes to be made during a Congress. The House's prohibition of non-germane amendments receives detailed coverage in the parliamentarian's annotations. The Clerk's Print contains the text of House Rules as amended, usually the first available document with the rules. The House adopts Rules at the start of each Congress, usually re-adopting previous Rules with amendments recommended by the majority party. The House Manual presents Rules clause by clause with annotations, allowing for changes to be made during a Congress. The recodification of the Rules reduced the number of rules from 52 to 28, with explanations provided in the Manual. The recodification of House Rules reduced the number of rules from 52 to 28, with explanations available on the House Committee on Rules website. Procedural regulations can be established through simple resolutions or statutory measures, which require agreement between both houses and the President. These procedures have the same standing as House and Senate rules. Statutory rule-making provisions give each chamber rule-making authority, subject to change through adoption of a simple resolution. These provisions establish procedures for congressional action on specified matters, including expedited procedures for executive branch proposals requiring congressional approval. Statutory rule-making provisions in the House Manual include expedited procedures for congressional action on executive branch proposals and regulations on the congressional budget process. The Legislative Reorganization Acts of 1946 and 1970 contain provisions currently regulating House procedure, with many incorporated into the Rules of the House. The parliamentarian's annotations in the House Manual discuss the origin and effect of these provisions on House procedures. The House Manual for the 110th Congress includes statutory legislative procedures that define special procedures for Congress to follow in disapproving or approving actions of the executive branch or independent agencies. These procedures create expedited processes for enacting joint resolutions of disapproval or approval, known as "privileged procedures," with the force of rules of the House and Senate. The House Manual outlines privileged procedures that establish expedited processes for Congress to approve or disapprove actions of the executive branch or independent agencies. These procedures have the force of rules of the House and Senate and are governed by various statutes, including the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 and the Defense Base Closure and Realignment Act of 1990. The House Manual outlines privileged procedures governed by statutes like the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985. Examples include sections of the Defense Base Closure and Realignment Act of 1990 and the Trade Act of 1974, which establish procedures for considering budgetary legislation in Congress. The Congressional Budget Act establishes procedures for considering budgetary legislation in the House and Senate, including special rules for the budget resolution and reconciliation legislation. The Act requires Congress to adopt a budget resolution each year to set spending, revenue, and deficit targets for the fiscal year. Budget resolutions may also include procedural regulations for subsequent actions. The budget resolution sets spending, revenue, and deficit targets for the fiscal year and allocates spending among budgetary categories. It may also include procedural regulations for subsequent actions on budget-related measures. The resolution is a concurrent measure that becomes effective upon agreement between the two houses, with procedural provisions operating similarly to statutory rule-making provisions. These provisions are considered an exercise of each house's constitutional authority over its rules. The procedural provisions in budget resolutions are considered an exercise of each house's constitutional authority over its rules. These provisions can be temporary or permanent, often concerning Senate procedures, and may have bicameral application. They are best identified by examining the texts of adopted congressional budget resolutions for successive years. The procedural provisions in budget resolutions are best identified by examining the texts of adopted congressional budget resolutions for successive years. These provisions institute new points of order against budgetary measures and are recorded in official publications of the House. House precedents in the Congressional Record are compiled in five official publications: House Practice, Deschler's Precedents, Hinds' and Cannon's Precedents, Procedure in the U.S. House of Representatives, and Cannon's Procedure. These publications provide comprehensive information on contemporary House procedure, including references to precedents and parliamentary authorities. Deschler's Precedents cover precedents from 1936, Hinds' Precedents from before 1906, and Cannon's Precedents from 1906 to 1936. The other two documents listed are predecessor documents of House Practice, presenting a digest of the House's current practice with citations. The House Practice publication is the most up-to-date reference source for House procedure, replacing older documents like Procedure in the U.S. House of Representatives. It was prepared by William Holmes Brown and contains rules, precedents, and procedures of the House. Members seeking precedents for parliamentary arguments should consult the Office of the House Parliamentarian for official advice. House Practice, prepared by William Holmes Brown and later updated by Charles W. Johnson III, is the modern reference source for House procedure. It covers 59 subjects in alphabetical order, with each chapter divided into topical sections and citations to other parliamentary reference sources. House Practice is a comprehensive parliamentary reference source for House procedure, covering 59 subjects in alphabetical order. Each chapter includes sections on general principles, main topics, and subtopics, with citations to other House parliamentary reference sources. Relevant chapters also provide terminology for parliamentary actions and rules governing budgetary legislation. The House Practice publication covers 59 subjects in alphabetical order, including a chapter on the rules and precedents governing House consideration of budgetary legislation. The index helps readers locate information on specific procedural topics, providing more detailed listings than the chapter outlines. Deschler's Precedents series contains significant recent precedents of the House, with 16 volumes published to date. Deschler's Precedents of the United States House of Representatives is a series of volumes initiated by Lewis Deschler and continued by his successors. The series covers precedents established after 1936, with volume 1 concluding at the first session of the 93rd Congress and volume 16 covering precedents through the 105th Congress. Citations to House Rules in these volumes refer to rule numbers and sections of the Manual before the House recodified its rules in the 106th Congress. The series Deschler's Precedents covers precedents established after 1936, with volume 1 concluding at the first session of the 93rd Congress and volume 16 covering precedents through the 105th Congress. Citations to House Rules in these volumes refer to rule numbers and sections of the Manual before the House recodified its rules in the 106th Congress. After the series is completed, revisions of each volume will be prepared, incorporating precedents established after the publication of the present edition. In Deschler's Precedents, topical sections are grouped under broader headings identified by letters. Each chapter begins with an introduction summarizing the principles presented by precedents. Individual precedents are numbered and cited by chapter and number. Subsections are headed by a catchline and bold headnote stating the principle, followed by the proceedings that establish the precedent. If the same proceedings illustrate multiple principles, each will be set forth in its own subsection. Deschler's Precedents contain procedural exchanges establishing precedents with citations to the Congressional Record. Some precedents include a "Parliamentarian's Note" for clarification. Each chapter has an index directing readers to relevant precedents. The chapters correspond to Procedure in the House, allowing for easy reference. The House procedures can be easily referenced using the index in Deschler's Precedents and Hinds' and Cannon's Precedents, which provide historical coverage up to 1936. Hinds' Precedents were written by Asher Hinds, while Cannon's Precedents were prepared by Clarence Cannon. Both series cover motions to adjourn and postpone. Volumes 6-11 of Cannon's Precedents, published in 1936 by Clarence Cannon, serve as a supplement to Hinds' Precedents. Cannon's Precedents include a chapter on the discharge rule, reflecting changes in House procedure. Sections are cited by volume and number. The House Manual cites sections by volume and number, presenting individual precedents with procedural exchanges and citations to the Congressional Record. Headnotes in bold type state the principle discussed, with some sections illustrating multiple principles in one proceeding. The House Manual cites sections by volume and number, presenting individual precedents with procedural exchanges and citations to the Congressional Record. Headnotes in bold type state the principle discussed, with some sections illustrating multiple principles in one proceeding. Where several consecutive sections illustrate the same principle, the headnote appears only for the first section. Proceedings that illustrate more than one principle are typically set forth in only one section, but with multiple headnotes. General discussion or background bearing on more than one principle may carry more than one headnote. Specific procedural topics can be located using the detailed table of contents in each volume and the comprehensive index arranged by topic and subtopic. Cannon's Procedure also serves as an index to Hinds' and Cannon's Precedents. Hinds' and Cannon's Precedents is a valuable reference source for House parliamentary procedure, but may be of limited practical value for contemporary practices. It is useful when other sources cite specific precedents from the 11-volume set. Procedure in the U.S. House of Representatives, also known as Deschler's Procedure, summarizes important House precedents from 1959 to 1980. House Practice was intended to replace Procedure, but knowledge of Procedure remains useful. The 1985 supplement discussing precedents from 1981 to 1984 was replaced in 1987 by one covering 1981 to 1986. Procedure is a valuable resource for House parliamentary procedure, organized in 37 chapters covering various topics. It can be used as an indirect means of locating materials in Deschler's Precedents. Procedure is a valuable resource for House parliamentary procedure, organized in 37 chapters covering various topics. Each chapter is divided into broad headings designated by letter, with numbered sections and paragraphs. When cited, Procedure is referenced by its title, chapter number, section or paragraph number, and page number. Most paragraphs state principles established by precedents or authorities, while some provide general principles or Parliamentarian's notes. A key difference between Procedure and Deschler's Precedents is highlighted. The supplement to Procedure is organized similarly to the main volume, with citations in the Congressional Record for specific precedents. It includes numbered paragraphs that replace corresponding ones in the main volume. The supplement to Procedure, organized like the main volume, includes numbered paragraphs that replace or add to corresponding ones in the main volume. It is a summary of major precedents from Hinds' and Cannon's Precedents, with additional precedents selected by Clarence Cannon. Cannon's Procedure includes thumb tabs for chapters, summaries of precedents with citations to Hinds' and Cannon's Precedents, and sample floor dialogues for parliamentary actions. Some dialogues are outdated, requiring informed judgment for use. The excerpt on "Suspension of the Rules" discusses obsolete features of the procedure. The House's procedures are governed by the Constitution, formal rules, and informal practices. These informal practices, although not officially adopted, supplement the rules and guide actions in the House. They establish consistent standards of action and provide additional guidance on proceedings. The Speaker's announced policies are one form of this procedural authority. The Speaker's announced policies and memorandums of understanding between committees are forms of procedural authority in the House. These policies, not official rules, guide the Speaker's exercise of authority under the Rules of the House. They are often developed in consultation with leaders of both parties and are reiterated at the start of each new Congress. The Speaker's announced policies in the House are not official rules but guide the Speaker's authority under the Rules of the House. These policies are reiterated at the start of each new Congress and cover various aspects such as privileges of the floor, introduction of measures, decorum in debate, and electronic voting procedures. The Speaker's policies in the House cover privileges of the floor, introduction of measures, decorum in debate, electronic voting procedures, and other forms of non-legislative debate. Standing committees create memorandums of understanding to clarify jurisdiction over policy issues, advising the Speaker on the referral of measures when jurisdiction is unclear. House Rules empower the Speaker to refer legislation to committees, with the Parliamentarian acting as the agent of the House. The Speaker's policies in the House cover privileges of the floor, introduction of measures, decorum in debate, and electronic voting procedures. Standing committees create memorandums of understanding to clarify jurisdiction over policy issues, advising the Speaker on the referral of measures when jurisdiction is unclear. House Rules empower the Speaker to refer legislation to committees, with the Parliamentarian acting as the agent of the House. Referral decisions are based on committee jurisdiction statements and relevant precedents, as well as memorandums of understanding. Memorandums of understanding have increased in importance due to rules changes in the House. They clarify jurisdiction over policy issues and designate a "primary" committee for referral of measures. Committees develop these agreements to specify jurisdiction, especially after jurisdiction transfers or abolitions of standing committees. An example is a memorandum of understanding between the committees on National Security and Transportation and Infrastructure from the 104th Congress. Memorandums of understanding clarify jurisdiction over policy issues and designate a "primary" committee for referral of measures. The internal structure of the House of Representatives includes committees and party conferences. Committees are responsible for developing legislative proposals, while party conferences assign members to leadership and committee roles. Each group has its own rules that impact House proceedings. The House Rules, particularly Rule XI, govern committee proceedings and actions. Each standing committee must adopt its own rules of procedure, covering aspects like quorum and voting requirements. These rules must align with House Rules and are enforced within the committee but not on the House floor. Committee rules must align with House Rules and are enforced within the committee but not on the House floor. A point of order in the House against defective committee procedures may be overruled unless in direct conflict with House rules. The House Committee on Rules compiles procedure rules from all standing committees each Congress, which are also published in the Congressional Record. House standing committees publish their rules in various forms such as pamphlets or legislative calendars. Rules of the House Democratic Caucus and Republican Conference are adopted during early organizational meetings after the November congressional election. Printed versions of the rules are distributed to members of the respective party without annotations or references. Rules of the conferences are created by the respective parties in the House. The rules of the House Democratic Caucus and Republican Conference are adopted during early organizational meetings after the November congressional election. Printed copies are issued only to party members and are not publicly available. These rules are not directly enforceable on the House floor but govern actions within the respective parties. They cover the selection and terms of party leaders, committee assignments, and House proceedings. The rules of the House Democratic Caucus and Republican Conference, adopted after the November congressional election, govern party leadership selection, committee assignments, and House proceedings. Rules include restrictions on considering legislation by suspension of the rules based on various criteria such as cost estimates and level of opposition. Additional publications offer information on House parliamentary procedure. Restrictions on requests for consideration by suspension of the rules are governed by party leadership rules. Various House publications provide valuable information on parliamentary procedure and practices, including the Floor Procedures Manual which offers practical guidance on parliamentary actions. The Floor Procedures Manual for the House of Representatives, currently in its 110th Congress edition, provides a concise guide to the legislative process. It includes a new section on House Rules regarding earmark provisions in legislation and an appendix with an Abridged Parliamentary Dictionary. Originally titled Floor Operations Manual, it was written by Robert E. Bauman for Republican Members and has since been updated by other leading Republicans. The "How Our Laws Are Made" document was first published in 1953 by the House Judiciary Committee and provides a summary of the legislative process focusing on House procedures. It has been revised and updated by leading Republican Members and distributed to House offices. The 23rd edition was published in 2003 and serves as a useful reference source for understanding the legislative process. The 23rd edition of How Our Laws Are Made, published in 2003, serves as a reference source for understanding House procedures. The document, prepared by the Office of the House Parliamentarian in consultation with the Office of the Senate Parliamentarian, reflects changes in congressional procedures since the 22nd edition. The Senate also provides a publication titled Enactment of a Law, which explains Senate floor procedures and the functions of Senate officials. It includes information on House and conference procedures, presidential action, and illustrations of key legislative process documents. The document Enactment of a Law provides information on House and conference procedures, presidential action, and illustrations of legislative process documents. It was last printed in 1981 but an updated online version was prepared in 1997 by Senate Parliamentarian Robert B. Dove. It includes a bibliography of House parliamentary reference sources. The House of Representatives has published various documents and precedents over the years, including Deschler's Precedents and Hinds' and Cannon's Precedents. These resources provide guidance on rules, procedures, and practices in the House. Various documents and publications related to the rules and procedures of the House of Representatives have been issued over the years, including the 1987 Supplement, Rules Adopted by the Committees of the House of Representatives, Rules of the House of Representatives, Jefferson's Manual, Floor Procedure in the U.S. House of Representatives, How Our Laws Are Made, and CRS Products. The House Republican Floor Manual was issued in January 1997 by the Office of the House Majority Leader. Various CRS Reports on the Committee System Rules Changes in the House of Representatives are available from the CRS Home Page. Various CRS Reports on Committee System Rules Changes in the House of Representatives are available from the CRS Home Page. These reports cover topics such as commonly used motions, conference committee procedures, early organization meetings, actions in the Committee of the Whole, the discharge rule, and legislative discipline in the House. The House discharge rule and other legislative procedures are covered in various CRS reports by different authors. Various CRS reports by different authors cover House Rules, Committee Markup Procedures, Voting Procedures, Legislative Process, Morning Hour Debates, Motion to Recommit, One-Minute Speeches, Points of Order, Conference Committees, and "Self-Executing" Rules. Various CRS reports by different authors cover House Rules, Committee Markup Procedures, Voting Procedures, Legislative Process, Morning Hour Debates, Motion to Recommit, One-Minute Speeches, Points of Order, Conference Committees, and "Self-Executing" Rules. The reports also provide information on online resources for House parliamentary reference sources. The appendix lists online resources for House parliamentary reference sources, including gateway websites like the Legislative Information System (LIS), GPO Access, and the House Committee on Rules website. Other Library of Congress and House of Representatives websites also provide documents on House parliamentary procedure. Internet addresses are provided for cited documents, but the list may not be exhaustive due to the constantly changing nature of online information. The Legislative Information System (LIS) is a resource available to Congress that provides information on House and Senate procedures, including links to GPO Access for parliamentary documents. The CRS Guides to Congressional Processes offer detailed information on legislative procedures in both chambers. The House Committee on Rules provides electronic versions of How Our Laws Are Made and Enactment of a Law, offering an overview of procedures in each chamber. The website includes links to House rules, procedural explanations, and various topics such as House Committee Procedures and Senate Process and Procedure. The House Rules Committee provides links to procedural publications and documents, including the Rules of the 110th Congress and Floor Procedure in the U.S. House of Representatives. GPO Access also offers searchable versions of the House Manual and The Constitution of the United States of America. A searchable version of the House Manual, The Constitution of the United States of America, and supplements are available through GPO Access. The Congressional Research Service also provides online versions of these documents. Other resources include links to rules of House committees, Library of Congress sites, and House of Representatives sites. The House Manual, Constitution of the United States, and supplements are available online. Links to House committee rules, Library of Congress sites, and House of Representatives sites are also provided.
